title: 111_hr6132
content: The Act may be cited as the "Veterans Benefits and Economic Welfare Improvement Act of 2010" and includes a table of contents. The "Veterans Benefits and Economic Welfare Improvement Act of 2010" includes provisions such as a military transition program, waiver of claim development period, tolling of review timing for appeals, exclusion of certain amounts from income determination for pensions, extension of income information authority, VetStar Award program, increase in pension for Medal of Honor recipients, and compliance with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010. The "Veterans Benefits and Economic Welfare Improvement Act of 2010" introduces a military transition program for eligible veterans to receive job market relevant training. Eligible veterans must meet specific criteria and be discharged under honorable conditions. The program established under the "Veterans Benefits and Economic Welfare Improvement Act of 2010" provides payments to employers for apprenticeship or on-the-job training for eligible veterans who meet certain criteria, including being unemployed for at least 90 days or receiving a maximum hourly rate of pay not exceeding 150 percent of the Federal minimum wage. The program requires approved training programs with pay rates equal to nonveterans in similar positions. The program established under the "Veterans Benefits and Economic Welfare Improvement Act of 2010" provides payments to employers for apprenticeship or on-the-job training for eligible veterans. The Assistant Secretary of Labor for Veterans' Employment and Training will enter into contracts with employers to provide programs that meet specific criteria, including equal pay rates for veterans and nonveterans in similar positions. The program established under the "Veterans Benefits and Economic Welfare Improvement Act of 2010" provides payments to employers for apprenticeship or on-the-job training for eligible veterans. Employers must meet specific criteria, including equal pay rates for veterans and nonveterans in similar positions. The amount paid to eligible veterans is 50% of their wages, calculated hourly. Payments are capped at $20,000 in total or $1,666.67 per month, and can only be made during the first 12 months of participation. The Assistant Secretary of Labor for Veterans' Employment and Training may extend payments for veterans in part-time programs. Payments under this section are capped at $20,000 in total and can be made for a maximum of 24 months. Employers must submit quarterly reports on wages paid to eligible veterans. $10,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year to carry out this program. The program is authorized to receive $10,000,000 annually and will terminate on September 30, 2016. Reporting on activities will be included in the annual report. Section 4115 of the Military transition program is added to various sections of the title, with amendments taking effect one year after enactment. Additionally, a waiver of claim development period for claims under laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs is included. The amendment to Section 5101 of title 38, United States Code, allows for expedited processing of fully developed claims submitted to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. Claimants can waive claim development periods for quicker treatment of their claims. The Secretary must notify claimants if a fully developed claim is not complete within 30 days. A fully developed claim is one where the claimant has received assistance or indicated they will not submit additional evidence. The term 'expeditious treatment' refers to processing and adjudicating a claim within 90 days after the application is received by the Secretary. Additionally, the Secretary must notify claimants if a fully developed claim is not complete within 30 days, where the claimant has indicated no need for additional evidence. The amendments made by this section allow for the availability of appeals forms and applications required by the Secretary for appealing decisions. These changes apply to claims submitted after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. TOLLING OF TIMING OF REVIEW FOR APPEALS OF FINAL DECISIONS OF BOARD OF VETERANS' APPEALS. Section 7266(a) of title 38, United States Code is amended to extend the 120-day period for filing a notice of appeal upon showing good cause, especially for those with service-connected disabilities. This amendment applies to appeals filed after July 24, 2008, regarding final decisions of the Board of Veterans' Appeals. Any petition for review dismissed by the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims after July 24, 2008, can be reinstated within six months of this Act's enactment if good cause is shown for the untimely filing. SEC. 5. EXCLUSION OF CERTAIN AMOUNTS FROM DETERMINATION OF ANNUAL INCOME FOR VETERANS AND SURVIVING SPOUSES AND CHILDREN. Certain Amounts Paid for Reimbursements and for Pain and Suffering are excluded from the determination of annual income for veterans and surviving spouses and children under section 1503(a) of title 38, United States Code. This includes reimbursements for expenses related to accidents, with a limit on the excluded amount based on fair market value or reasonable replacement value. The excluded amounts for reimbursements related to accidents are based on fair market value or reasonable replacement value of the item involved. The excluded amounts for reimbursements related to accidents are based on fair market value or reasonable replacement value of the item involved, including medical expenses resulting from accidents, theft, loss, or casualty loss. The excluded amounts for reimbursements related to accidents are based on fair market value or reasonable replacement value of the item involved, including medical expenses resulting from accidents, theft, loss, or casualty loss. Section 1503(a) of title 38, United States Code, is amended to specify certain amounts paid by States and Municipalities as Veterans Benefits. The amendments made to Section 1503(a) of title 38, United States Code, include the payment of a monetary amount of up to $5,000 to a veteran from a State or municipality as a veterans' benefit due to injury or disease. These amendments will apply to determinations of income for calendar years beginning after October 1, 2011. SEC. 6. Extension of authority for Secretary of Veterans Affairs to obtain income information from other agencies extended to September 30, 2015. SEC. 7. Vetstar Award Program. SEC. 7. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will establish the "VetStar Award Program" to recognize businesses for their contributions to veterans' employment. Criteria for eligibility and selection will be established. SEC. 8. The amount of pension for Medal of Honor recipients will increase from $1,000 to $2,000. SEC. 9. Compliance with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010. SEC. 9. Compliance with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010. The budgetary effects of this Act will be determined by reference to the latest statement for compliance with the Act. Passed the House of Representatives on September 28, 2010.
